items.question: What is phishing?
items.answer: Phishing is a scam where attackers impersonate trusted parties (email, websites, SMS) to steal credentials, money or sensitive data. Be cautious with unexpected links and requests for passwords or OTPs.

items.question: What are common phishing signs?
items.answer: Common signs: urgent language, poor grammar, mismatched sender domains, suspicious links, and unexpected attachments. Hover links to see their real target before clicking.

items.question: Phishing vs vishing vs smishing
items.answer: Phishing = email/web scams, vishing = voice call scams, smishing = SMS scams. All try to trick you into revealing sensitive information.

items.question: How do phishing emails look?
items.answer: They often use urgent warnings, fake sender names, and links that don't match the displayed text. Example: 'Your account will be closed. Click https://bank.example.verify-login.com to reactivate.' The domain is a clueâ€”don't click.

items.question: How to check if a link is safe?
items.answer: Hover the link to preview the URL, check for typos or extra subdomains, use a URL scanner, and avoid shortened links from unknown senders.

items.question: Show an example phishing email
items.answer: Example: 'Attention: Update your account now: https://secure-bank-login.example.com' â€” notice the odd subdomain and urgency. Always verify the sender domain separately.

items.question: I clicked a scam link â€” what now?
items.answer: Close the page, do NOT enter credentials. Clear browser cache, change passwords for affected accounts, enable 2FA, and run antivirus. Contact your bank if you shared payment details.

items.question: I shared my password â€” what should I do?
items.answer: Immediately change the password for that account and for any other account using the same password. Enable two-factor authentication and check for unusual activity.

items.question: Steps to recover a compromised account
items.answer: Reset password, enable 2FA, remove unknown devices/sessions, contact support, and check transactions or sent messages for abuse.

items.question: What is UPI fraud and how to avoid it?
items.answer: UPI fraud includes social engineering, fake payment approvals, and QR-code scams. Never share your UPI PIN or approve payments you didn't initiate.

items.question: What to do if money was sent to a scammer?
items.answer: Contact your bank immediately with transaction IDs and timestamps. File a police complaint and ask the bank for a possible reversal.

items.question: How to report cybercrime in my country?
items.answer: Report to your local police cyber unit and to your bank. Many countries have online cybercrime portalsâ€”search your national police or government site for reporting steps.

items.question: Who to contact for bank/fraud help?
items.answer: Contact your bank's fraud helpline immediately. They can block transactions, freeze accounts, and advise next steps.

items.answer: I can't automatically scan attachments. Upload the file (if the interface supports it) or paste the text; I will guide you how to inspect it safely.

items.question: Short checklist to share with colleagues
items.answer: Checklist: 1) Don't click unknown links; 2) Verify sender addresses; 3) Use 2FA; 4) Report suspicious emails; 5) Keep software updated.
